title: Data feminism
author: Catherine D'Ignazio and Lauren F. Klein

title: Technology is Not Neutral - A Short Guide to Data Ethics
author: Stephanie Hare

title: How Do You Know If You Are Making a Difference? A Practical Handbook for Public Service Organisations
author: Sarah Morton and Ailsa Cook
Description: We are trying to move towards outcome map based evaluation of projects. I was recommended How Do You Know If You Are Making a Difference? to understand this better.

title: Clean Code
author: Robert Cecil Martin
Description: I recently read *The Clean Code* by Robert Cecil Martin - I'm not a coder but thought it was very good. The book is about professionalism for developers (similar to accountants etc.) and give you some tools to help prevent feeling under pressure re: timescales.  It's not a recent book yet very relevant to some incidents that have happened lately

title: Asking the right questions: a guide to critical thinking
author: M. Neil Browne and Stuart M. Keeley
details: Research IT Facilitator at NHS Tayside
Description: think this will go well with this (mine is the 7th ed. which is linked here, I think it is up to the ?12th ed. now), which used to be a mandatory reading for my Communications (PR) dip. nearly 2 decades ago - one of the chapters is dedicated in looking at whether presented stats are deceptive:

title: The 7 Deadly Sins of Psychology
author: Chris Chambers
details: Senior Information Analyst at Public Health Scotland
Description: Highly recommend "The 7 Deadly Sins of Psychology" by Chris Chambers. All about pitfalls in real-world scientific methodology and what we can do to combat them. The title says "psychology" but it applies more broadly.

title: Thinking Fast and Slow
author: Daniel Kahneman
details: Senior Analyst at NHS Education for Scotland
Description: "Very popular bestselling book that discusses cognitive biases and why humans are generally bad at assessing risk and interpreting statistics. Some of the research [cited in the book was found to be unsound](https://replicationindex.com/2020/12/30/a-meta-scientific-perspective-on-thinking-fast-and-slow/) and Kahneman himself said ['I placed too much faith in underpowered studies'](https://retractionwatch.com/2017/02/20/placed-much-faith-underpowered-studies-nobel-prize-winner-admits-mistakes/).  [Its an interesting read](https://quality1supplements.com/daniel-kahneman-was-sometimes-wrong-and-always-right/)
